And the Government's own expert testified in this case that there are many foreign countries in which the law that's considered criminally indecent here would be perfectly lawful.
So there would be that--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So Congress could cure this constitutional defect as you see it simply by making it clear that the law applied everywhere?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --No, it wouldn't cure the second problem, Your Honor, because that would then be a conflict with the laws of those many foreign countries--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but supposing the Congress said we don't care if there's a conflict?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, Congress could violate that standard of statutory interpretation.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, when Congress expressly provides something, it's not violating a standard of statutory interpretation.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, I... I agree that Congress could have drafted a much different statute than the one it drafted.
It could have drafted a statute that did not apply at all to noncommercial speakers.
It did not.
It could have drafted a statute that only applied to visual images, not just four-letter words.
It could have drafted a statute that was, in many respects, narrower than the statute at issue here.
It could have limited it to prurient speech that lacked serious value.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But I'm talking about broader statute.
A broader statute, in that respect, saying that it was all over the world that it applied, would cure this one constitutional defect that you're talking about.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: It would take care of that defect.
But that's not the statute we have before us.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, I'm not sure.

While I certainly agree that normally statutes are not interpreted to be extraterritorial, I don't know that we've ever had a case in which it has been asserted that the difference between the constitutionality and unconstitutionality of the statute is whether it is extraterritorial.
I think if the only way to make it constitutional is to interpret it as being extraterritorial, I'm not sure that we wouldn't say, well--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Justice Scalia, this is not that case.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --I mean if that's your only argument, I'm saying--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: It's not... it's not the only argument.
It's not the only argument at all.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --I think it's a pretty weak argument.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: But it's not the only argument at all, Justice Scalia.
Our argument--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I thought you were making the point that it would be ineffective because--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --but not unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: It would be ineffective for that reason.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: But even if... excuse me, Justice--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --you did bring up an interesting point.
Are there other nations that have regulated indecent speech in cyberspace?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --Not that I know of, Justice Ginsburg.
There may be.
But there are other nations that have attempted to regulate the content of speech in cyberspace.
China attempts to regulate speech that's critical of the Chinese Government.
It's not inconceivable that Iran might attempt to regulate speech that's critical of religious--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And might want to control the world with respect to that, to rule the world with respect to the kind of speech that that nation doesn't like?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, Justice Ginsburg, I think... in fact, the Chamber... U.S. Chamber of Commerce filed an amicus brief in this case, criticizing this law for precisely that reason... that this law sends precisely the wrong signal.

That it is appropriate for governments, in their own interest, to ban whatever speech they want to ban from a global medium, which will cripple the competitiveness of U.S. business in competing in this increasingly important business--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I suppose we better let obscenity in, too, then?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's just the point.
If that's a global principle--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --I don't think obscenity--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Right.
--if we shouldn't ban stuff that we don't like, it would apply to obscenity.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --I don't think obscenity is considered appropriate or lawful speech in any country that I'm aware of.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, but I do think it's a weak argument to say that the United States, if it has a strong public policy, cannot lead the way, and maybe other nations would follow.
I think your argument is... is not your strongest argument.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: No, that's not our strongest argument.
Our strongest argument, Justice Kennedy, is that this law will have the unconstitutional effect of banning indecent speech from adults in all of cyberspace.
For 40 years, this Court has repeatedly and unanimously ruled that Government cannot constitutionally reduce the adult population to reading and viewing only what is appropriate for children.
That is what this law does.
In Sable, this Court, in the telephone context, struck down a law that had precisely that effect.
It banned telephone indecent speech.
And that had the unlawful effect of banning that speech from adults, as well as from minors.
This Court unanimously struck that down.

And to answer Justice Breyer's question about telephone, I do not believe it is a crime in this country today for private persons, including private teenagers, to communicate indecent speech by telephone.
It would be a crime to communicate exactly the same speech under the CDA.
So, returning, the principal arguments we have is that this is a ban on adult speech.
It is not going to be effective, for the reasons I've expressed, about all of the foreign indecent speech.

And even if it were effective, there are less-restrictive alternatives that enable parents, completely, to decide what they think is appropriate for their 17-year-old, as opposed to their 16-year-old.
Under this law, there is no parental choice.
The Government decides what's appropriate for all 17-year-olds.
A parent who disagrees with the Government cannot, through the Internet, gain access to speech, safer sex information, very similar to the information at issue in the Bolger case.
That parent would have no opportunity, using the Internet, to make that speech available to the parent's 17-year-old child.

And even worse than the hypothetical you asked, Justice Souter, about the 2 years in jail, for a parent to send an indecent E-mail message to the parent's 17-year-old college freshman son or daughter.
That's a direct transmission, not just a permitting the use.
The parent would... would be committing a criminal act to do that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Ennis, do you think it would be constitutional to require all transmitters to tag their material?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think it would raise significant compelled speech questions, Justice Stevens.
Whether it be constitutional or not, I don't know.
But even if that were required, that would not--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If it's not, then that's not a less-restrictive alternative?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, it wouldn't be a less-restrictive alternative under the way this law is worded.
Because this law makes it a crime to make speech available.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, I'm assuming you just start from scratch, with a law that requires that as the principal means of screening.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: I think... I think what would be constitutional is what this Court found would be constitutional in Denver Area.
And that is encouraging, facilitating parents to use the parental control options that are readily available to them right now.
If parents use the software tools they have, they can block or screen all indecent speech.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Nothing with any teeth in it?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Well, you could--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They're not readily available without labelling.
That's the problem.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --No, no--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Without tagging.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --That's wrong, Justice Scalia.
Right now... I'm a parent.
I subscribe to one of the major online service providers.
I clicked the kid's only box.
And that means my child does not have any access to the Internet unless I'm there to supervise.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Does the Government have any interest in protecting children who do not have parents available in the home or do not have adequate parental supervision?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Justice Kennedy, we do not dispute that the Government has a legitimate interest in protecting some children from some forms of speech that could be found indecent.

But the problem with this law is, in order to achieve that objective, it completely bans all of that speech from adults and also bans it from the substantial portion of minors who themselves have first amendment rights, under Bolger and Erznoznik, to have access to the banned speech.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Ennis, if I had to be present whenever my 16-year-old is on the Internet, I would know less about this case than I know today.
[Laughter]
That is simply not a realistic possibility... to tell every parent, if you're worried about it, just don't let your teenager use the Internet unless you're there.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: That's the point, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's not reasonable.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: That's the point.
The parental control devices that are available on the Internet are more effective than any control devices available for broadcast TV, cable or telephone, because the parents don't have to be there.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Ennis.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Waxman, you have a minute remaining.

turn.speaker: seth_p_waxman
turn.label: Mr. Seth P. Waxman
turn.text: I have five points.
I will try and make them very quickly.
The burden of proof... this is an act of Congress that's being challenged on its face... the burden of proof, under long precedent, is with the party challenging it.
That's verified by Federal Rule of Evidence 301, and this Court's precedence in Walters and Hicks v. St. Mary's Honor Center.

With respect to the classification burden on the Carnegie Library, this Court's precedence in the obscenity context have indicated that there is no obligation for the Carnegie Library to read every one of its books in order to decide it has to be classified.
In order to prove a criminal case, we have to prove that the defendant actually knew the content.
So the Carnegie Library only has to do what it has to do under its local ordinance, which is take the indecent stuff and put it in a different room.
This is the electronic equivalent of that.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But that's' not true under the display... that's not true under the display provision here, is it?

turn.speaker: seth_p_waxman
turn.label: Mr. Seth P. Waxman
turn.text: It is true under the display provision.
That is, if they find that they have certain--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I thought that was not a knowing offense?

turn.speaker: seth_p_waxman
turn.label: Mr. Seth P. Waxman
turn.text: --Excuse me?

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: The display provision is not a knowing offense.

turn.speaker: seth_p_waxman
turn.label: Mr. Seth P. Waxman
turn.text: Well, you have to knowingly display it.

And it, in the context... if I may just finish this point... it, in the context of this Court's decisions in the patently offensive prong of the obscenity context, has said that whatever the standard of proof, whatever the scienter is, you may not, as a constitutional matter, convict somebody unless you prove not that they knew that it was pornographic, but that--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I think you've... I think you've... Mr. Waxman, I think you've answered the question.

turn.speaker: seth_p_waxman
turn.label: Mr. Seth P. Waxman
turn.text: --Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The case is submitted.
